author: Vincent Bonsignore
title: Bonsignore: Sarkisian needs to get right— but so does USC, which needs to turn the page
text:
NEW YORK >> First and foremost, we wish nothing but the best for USC coach Steve Sarkisian. Whatever issues he’s dealing with , we offer him support, well wishes and prayers.
This isn’t about football or winning and losing or game plans.
This is about life.
And by all accounts Sarkisian is in the fight of his life .
His future, personally and professionally, hangs in the balance.
We all have his back.
But if you are USC, it’s time to move on from Sarkisian and identify and hire a coach the Trojans can rely on, lean on, depend on and expect to carry one of the great football programs in the country back to national prominence.
Sarkisian isn’t that coach. For various reasons, probably.
Some of which have to do with ability.
But that’s subjective, isn’t it?
What we do know, what’s been made painfully clear over the last month and last few days is that Sarkisian has much more serious issues to deal with than coming up with a game plan to beat Notre Dame and UCLA and recruiting and developing the next USC Heisman Trophy winner.
And we all hope he finds the peace and balancing that is eluding him.
Doesn’t matter who you root for, either. From every corner of the Pac-12 to across college football, this is one of those moments we should set aside rooting interest and focus on what’s really important.
There is sports and there is life.
This is life.
Something isn’t right with Sarkisian . There is a problem .
Based on the events of Sunday, when Sarkisian reportedly showed up to work in no condition to do his job and USC athletic director Pat Haden not only asked Sarkisian to leave, he put him on indefinite leave of absence, it’s obvious the Trojans second-year coach has some serious issues to deal with.
We won’t speculate what those problems are, but Sarkisian himself admitted last month he mixed medication with alcohol at a school-sponsored event with USC donors in late August. The result was an ugly and embarrassing video that went viral in which Sarkisian staggered about slurring his speech and making outlandish comments.
He was obviously drunk .
He was obviously out of control .
But we gave him a pass.
One of those nights. Some of us have been there before. Have a drink or two too many, someone hands you the mike, and, well, you get the picture.
In retrospect we should have all seen beyond just a guy mistakenly mixing a drink or two too many with whatever medication he was on. We should have realized something bigger and scarier was in play.
But we cut him some slack.
Then came Sunday when USC players reportedly noticed Sarkisian wasn’t sober during a special teams meeting. Haden stepped in, took one look at his coach and sent him home.
Advertisement
Then Haden announced Sarkisian was going on indefinite leave.
As the day unfolded reports of other incidents surfaced, including ones in which Sarkisian may or may not have been intoxicated on flights to and from USC games and on the field.
It raises serious questions about what was known and who knew it, but finger-pointing will be left for another day.
Right now it’s about getting Sarkisian right and about what is right for USC moving forward.
More and more it looks like that should mean moving on without Sarkisian.
Defensive coordinator Clay Helton takes over on an interim basis and will coach the Trojans on Saturday when they take on longtime rival Notre Dame in South Bend.
Whatever Sarkisian is dealing with. Whatever demons he’s facing. We wish him the best.
That’s the life side of this complex coin.
But there is another side, and it’s the 100 or so kids on the USC roster and the remaining coaches and staff members and everybody who works or supports USC football.
And they all deserve a leader they can count on and a coach they can truly have faith in.
That doesn’t appear to be Sarkisian.
Not right now, for sure.
And who really knows when or if he ever will?
It’s time to cut ties with Sarkisian, who obviously needs and deserves the time and space to focus on himself and work through whatever personal problems he’s dealing with.
He’s still young. He still has a future. If he can get himself right, he will land on his feet somewhere and hopefully reach as high and as far as he is capable.
But USC deserves better.
His current and future players do as well.
We can wish the best for Sarkisian while also understanding the best for USC is turning the page, cutting ties and looking for a long-term answer as the Trojans head football coach.
Sarkisian deserves the time and space to get his life back in order.
But his job shouldn’t necessarily be waiting for him when he does.
